Rainbow: Nisha Rokubou no Shichinin. This anime goes into the dark theme of seven teenagers forced to suffer for their crimes in a detention facility just after the WWII. The story follows these seven teenagers in trying to survive the cruelty of the warden and the detention center in general. The story progression may be a bit slow at times but it surely delivers. Story: 8/10
The theme of the art is generally dark which makes perfect sense for what it is trying to portray. The animation is superb and the style is very suiting. Art: 9/10
The sound, even though nothing too unique or amazing, waspretty enjoyable to say the least. Most of the soundtracks were suited for the occasion and used very well. Sound: 8/10


In my opinion, the best part of this anime are the characters and character development. In terms of side-characters it may have been sub-par as side-characters weren't given too much attention and development. However, it more than made up for this fault by the development and illustration of the main characters, which there were seven of. As these characters are made to be real life like, you can relate to each one and would generally take a liking to most, if not all, of them. In terms of main characters, this anime does it especially well. Character: 9/10


In terms of enjoyment, Rainbow certainly succeeded to keep me entertained throughout the series. It manages well to play well with your emotions where you would find yourself smiling whenever something pleasant happens, angered or sorrowed whenever during a woeful moment and sitting on the edge of your seat for the most part. Enjoyment: 9/10


Do I recommend this anime? Yes, definitely a must-watch. Overall: 8.4/10

'Grasshoppers can fly, so can birds. Yet.....aren't we even allowed to dream'
Growing up and living in an environment where a struggle is present every moment of your life can only take a toll on ones psyche. You have no friends and  either have no family or, the family you have are troubled or distant from what they previously were. The only way to survive is by trusting no one but yourself as past experiences have dictated your innate perception of people. They are selfish and only get by; by looking out for themselves. Hate breeds hate, loneliness too does the same. This is theenvironment and setting of 'Rainbow: Nisha Rokubou no Shichinin 'or 'The Criminal Seven of Compound Two , Cell Six'.


For me this series had everything an anime enthusiast could ask for; a gripping story, character development and the right mixture of genres encompassing the life and times of the cast. This series on completion left me wanting more but, also gave utmost satisfaction at where it finished. Like any good series it grabbed me within the first episode. For me beginning a new series at times can be daunting as a number of them take a while to get into. Rainbow on the other hand excelled at the opposite. I was hooked!


I personally enjoy the opening and ending themes of a series as they begin and end your viewing of an episode/series. Both themes were amazing and portrayed the themes and symbols of the series. 'We're not alone' by Coldrain starts the episode; the lyrics of the song encompass what those of the cast should be realizing. That you are not alone in this world and by standing together anything is possible. The ending is 'A far off distance' by Galneryus which is a reflective and a guitar wrenching powerballad showing the struggle and promise the cast have in life.


To keep me from rambling on i will be straight too the point with the remainder of the review.


The story was heartfelt, a tear jerker but at times it could be said a little too over emotional. However, looking back and taking all factors into account this was needed to show the effect that ones values can have on their life. For me the biggest let down of this anime in which everything was a 10/10, was the story as I longed for more. 9/10


Sound and Art will classed under Animetography; which i believe was one of the best aspects of the series. The detail in the facial expressions of the characters and settings would have to be up there with the best of series. As a viewer it really gave me a feel of the life the cast lived. The use of still  shots was also a key upside to this anime as it created a lasting impression something that at times would playback to you throughout the series.


The music was fantastic encompassing mood perfectly and really setting the bar in terms of tempo and speed the anime progressed in. Overall both a 10/10


Koyama Rikiya lead the cast of the series and showed why in my eyes he is one of the best in the business. Possibly some of the best voice actors i have heard take part in this series and really encompass what are individual brings to the table. Yet again 10/10


Impression or enjoyment was also a 10/10. Like i said earlier the only let down was the anime actually ending.


As anime watchers i implore you to watch this series as it is one of the best stories to have come out of Japan in recent years. A tale of friendship and a never give up lifestyle encompass the series. Without giving detail or providing spoilers to the series i hope this persuades you into watching and getting your friends to watch as well. One of the key things about this anime is the lack of awareness people have to it.


'We all wish to fly freely in the sky'

In the aftermath of the most devastating war in history, inside a reformatory, an unbreakable friendship is born between seven children.
There probably aren't many anime that can depict a friendship between a group of men as good as Rainbow. This group of friends will try to survive to a very harsh environment, and their friendship will prove to be their biggest weapon.
In the 50s, Japan was really in a very poor state because of World War II, and this anime makes it a goal to really show the viewers a bit of how things were back then; how much injustice was all over and howhuman rights were violated daily, specially in a place like a reformatory. It was a hard life, and many people suffered a lot.


Our characters are challenged by many difficulties, which of course, included the relation between them sometimes, but everything will end up making their ties stronger. Prison is, obviously, not a friendly place, and many thing will happen in there to make our main characters act in extreme ways.


This is an engaging series from the first moment. If you like it, you will probably get hooked immediately and until the end, making this a very enjoyable series.


Music is also a very big element here, and it's played beautifully, from the opening to the ending, going through some great insert songs and a glorious BGM consisting in various tunes. You can expect great things when you have Masafumi Mima as sound director (Full Metal Alchemist, NANA, Shingeki no Kyojin, among many).


If you like what we commonly refer to as GAR (very manly characters), you're coming to the right place, as many of our characters being great examples of it, specially Rokurouta Sakuragi, who is very well voiced by Rikiya Komaya (Kiritsugu in Fate/Zero, Kogoro from Detective Conan, Takamura from Hajime no Ippo), and is probably one of the finest examples of "GAR" you'll ever find.


Animation is really good throughout the whole series, with Madhouse doing an extremely good job in pretty much every aspect of the anime. There are some cruel things shown, because, just like Madhouse makes it clear at the start of every episode, they really want to portray the atmosphere of that period.


The anime is basically divided in two halves divided but a timeskip, with the first half being the clear superior one, but with the second one still being pretty solid.


The first half is mainly about the life of this group inside the reformatory and about how they forge such a great bond. The second half is more about their life after the reformatory, and how that friendship proves to be something unbreakable.


Biggest problem in this anime would be the antagonists, who are guys that are so evil, that they really aren't that believable as characters, even if their reasons were actually pretty common in places like that. They're there to be hated, and they make them very "hateable"... to a fault.


This is an anime pretty hard to dislike, as it is pretty solid in every aspect, and maybe you can even get to learn a little bit about what is to be in a place that was devastated by war.


Madhouse is already a studio full of great works, and Rainbow is among the very best of them.

Rainbow really is an anime of two halves. There is a tonal shift that happens about halfway through that completely changes the feel and the quality of the story. This is not a good thing in my opinion. Lets look at each half and assess its quality.
The story starts out in post-war Japan with a bunch of young delinquents being stuck in the same jail cell of a reformatory for young men. This half of the anime concentrates solely on the boys being subjected to some absolutely horrific treatment by the warden and one particular guard, whilst looking for an opportunity to escape. Now fairwarning, this portion of the story is REALLY DARK. Holy shit, it might be some of the darkest, most effed up stuff Ive ever seen in an anime!!! Without going into detail, it involves regular beatings, child rape, torture, and eventually straight up attempted murder. And the villains are portrayed in the most mindlessly evil way possible: by this i mean the way they're animated as snarling drooling demons basically, with no actual motivation for their actions other than "these guys are are just pure evil". In fact the vast majority of adults in Rainbow are portrayed as evil....so while some elements of the story feel faithful to the place and time, the portrayal of people is very cartoony, with little motivation for their actions. Basically, the young guys are good, the bad guys are pure evil. What im trying to get across is that Rainbow is not a subtle anime at all. Nevertheless, the first half is powerful, as we see these boy's friendship strengthen through their shared adversity. It feels a lot like "Shawshank Redemption" in this regard. 


Now, without spoiling it too much, eventually the boys leave the reformatory and try to make their way in the real world. This is basically the storyline for the entire second half of the series. This is where Rainbow falls flat in my opinion. The tone of the series changes drastically, with a lot more light hearted feel. Dont worry, there's still lots of beatings, just less paedophiles and kiddy rape. The leader of the boys ***SPOILER*** gets killed (in an absolutely ridiculous way it must be said), and this prompts each of the boys to decide what they want to do with their future. Now this sounds ok on paper, but the execution is so over the top dramatic and unrealistic it really makes your eyes roll. To give an example, one of the boys wants to become a singer. Fair enough, nothing wrong with that. However, the band he is apprenticing for decide for some reason that because he wants to become a singer he is their competition and that they must teach him a lesson by beating the crap out of him, threatening to pour mercury down his throat, and eventually trying to murder him. For absolutely NO REASON. Its contrived drama that just would never happen in real life. This is the over the top ridiculous cartoony tone of the series second half,and i feel it really suffers from this inept writing.


The animation is generally and consistently really nice, to its credit it rarely looks low budget. Sound is also pretty good, and its got a killer opening theme song by Coldrain (reminiscent of Hunter x Hunter's epic metalcore opening). 


Those that applaud Rainbow as masterpiece are simply way off the mark. It explores some dark, horrific themes, that do reflect the hard times of post war Japan. But instead of a realistic portrayal, they went for over the top drama and torture porn. Basically its content is meant to shock, not to make a thought provoking point.

Another beautiful anime. Rainbow is truly an underrated gem that I happen to stumble upon and I was really amazed of how well everything is made in this anime and how well it showed the values of love, friendship and hope is very important in life.
Story-10
The story is about teens who were sent to a detention facility where they meet a fellow inmate who changed they're lives for the better. Throughout the series this fellow inmate has been their inspiration to endure everything in life, move forward and shape their future.
The story is pretty simple and a little slow but it is delivered perfectly asthere are no loose ends throughout the series and everything is wrapped up perfectly in the end.


Art-10

Art is amazing and animated very well with very vibrant colors.


Sound-9

The music is very good especially joe's song which is a very powerful moment for his character and so are the sound effects and the dubbing of the voice actors as I could really feel the emotions every character is portraying and what the mood of the scene is.


Characters-9

Characters are amazing in this anime. I could not find any of the protagonists that I don't care about because they are presented as real human characters which could exist in real life. 


Throughout the series every protagonist is well fleshed out and none of them are really "useless" which many anime series fails at.


My only complain here is the lack of a good villain since all of them in the series are either not developed enough or a cliche very sinister looking/over the top "evil bad guy type."


Enjoyment-10

The series is very entertaining for me  and it is one of the only few shows that mad me shed manly tears of bot sorrow and joy. Watching how the characters persevere through their struggles and the message of friendship, love and hope good enough for me to invest valuable time in finishing this series.


Overall-9

All in all it is almost a perfect 10 for me but nonetheless I consider this anime one of the best I have ever watched and for those who like drama and tragedy with a good message, you should definitely give this a try.

"Even 1% would be enough for me."
-Mario Minakami
Rainbow was a series I found completely by accident.  Perusing the top anime on MAL I was surprised to see something I hadn't even heard of.  It isn't necessarily popular, but most of those who have seen it seem to hold it in high regard.  After having the pleasure of watching Rainbow, I can fully understand the praise that many hold for it.  A slight disclaimer is to be had though, don't expect many victories in Rainbow.  Shows like this and Kaiji focus more on preserverance and the ultimate test of will tosend a powerful message to its viewers than relying on lighthearted comedy or fanservice.  It is certainly a poignant tale, and is one that will leave you with a strong sympathy for the characters it follows. 


Rainbow, produced by the infamous Madhouse follows the lives of seven delinquents sent to a detention center in Japan sometime after World War II.  Right away I was intrigued by the uniqueness of the setting.  It felt rather refreshing to become immersed in a world so different than our own, where a country was riddled with foreigners and was trying to get back on its feet after the bomb that leveled Hiroshima.  It really puts the entire story into perspective when you know the fragility of the populace. The on-edge vibe that the passengers aboard the bus in the opening sequence gave towards the prisoners being transported to juvenile detention really hit the nail on the head.  At one point, one of the future protagonists attempts to return a stuffed animal dropped by a small child and is berated and ridiculed by the child's mother for doing so.  It just immersed the setting in a cold, apathetic veil that spoke volumes.


Rainbow held nothing back in its depictions of the beatings and mistreatings the 7 of them went through in their time at the detention center.  There were brutal beatings, forced suicides and sexual assaults among the horrendous acts committed by the faculty members within the reformatory.  Nothing is left unsaid with regard to the malpractice going on in the Shonan Special Reform school. The characters in Rainbow are all unique and justifiable in their own way.  I am grateful that Madhouse decided to slate the series for 26 episodes vice 12 or 13, because I don't think the proper amount of development could have gone into 7 different characters with that few of episodes.  Initially the group was on guard and rather stand-offish towards one another, but grew closer due to the constant struggles they underwent in the juvenile detention center.  Sakuragi, the eventual leader of the outcasts served as the ultimate pariah, and often took the beatings for the group's wrongdoings.


When I said there aren't many victories to expect, the first half of the series really emphasizes this. Thrown into literal squalor, the 7 delinquents all vary in personality and background, which makes their assimilation all the more interesting. You have a Hiroshima survivor, a thief and an almost innocent soul who all end up in the same figurative undertow, and their treatment can make more squeamish individuals cower in nausea. Unfortunately I can't help but come to the realiztion that their treatment was relatively common in those days.  If you do a little research back to the 40's, Japan was so fragile that you could break souls of the populace by touching them.  Everyone was on edge from defeat, and being an American gave me an interesting perspective while watching the show.  I've seen retrospective anime before, but few truly illustrate the environment better than Rainbow does.  It's truly an immersive experience.


I won't give too much away when it comes to the plot, but what I will say is that it brought a grown man to tears.  There are many powerful, emotional moments in this series, and some that truly left me at a loss for words.  And it is truly a tale of two halves.  The first half is dark and treacherous, while the second offers a glimmer of hope, personified by the golden finch that flies about in the show's OP.  The second half almost seemed like a different anime entirely, but it was warranted based on how the characters were treated in the first half.  Truly showing how a detention center can shape one's mind, the kids in Rainbow had a difficult time adjusting to society upon leaving the institution.  I kept saying when the show was elapsing, “why aren't more anime like this?” Too many times, shows rely on stale comedy, recycled ideas and perverted ecchi to get their views.  The industry is starting to become watered down and are losing their charm.  Diehard fans really need more shows like Rainbow to instill a sense of hope for future anime.


The cast of Rainbow is actually rather small, considering there are 7 main protagonists.  Among the main protagonists, Mario was by far my favorite, and he received more depth than anyone.  His history, and emulation of Sakuragi was uncanny and really made you root for him.  It's often said that desperation brings out the best in people, and in Mario's case this is true.  To respect someone enough to have your own body crippled in return for their salvation speaks volumes for your character.  Having the friends of a lifetime also helps though, as Mario's fellow cell mates rose from the ashes together. I loved watching the stories of Turtle and Joe unfold.  Joe was so desperate to reunite with his sister that it seemed his persistence for stardom was more for her than him.  He was a selfless sould who sell his own body if it meant he could one day see his sister again. I also enjoyed seeing some backstory on Uncovered, since his eventual cooperation was what saved Sakuragai from dying within the confines of the facility.  I can definitely relate with his struggles being dirt poor.  I grew up not knowing where my next meal would come from, and sometimes we end up hurting those we love the most out of confusion and frustration. I wished more development would've existed with Soldier, as he was the only major character without an episode or two devoted to him in the second half, but with a 26 episode limit, somebody had to get slighted.


Ishihara, the main guard of the detention center assigned to the 7 delinquents certainly did his best to act the part.  There are few characters in anime I have ever wanted to rip through the screen and strangle... but Ishihara definitely takes the cake. There were small issues I had with the rest of the cast, including the PTSD Turtle experienced so late after the events at Hiroshima.  Granted I'm not a medical expert, but it seemed awful convnient for his symptoms to start right when his dual episode after story was due to air.  Also, I'm curious as to what kind of doctor would be able to repair a disintegrated hand so flawlessly and allow him to fight full strength in a boxing match in such a short amount of time.  Not to mention the fact that this anime took place in the 1940's.  Nevertheless, these are just minor issues, and nothing to change my overall opinion of the show.


Ok, we can all admit that Rainbow's OP is incredible.  There is a running playlist of anime music I have on youtube which I rarely add to, but I definitely made an exception for this song.  The lyrics cried in angst, redemption and hopefulness, and I loved the way it opened each episode. The ED was also really powerful in its own right, and I urge you to look up the lyrics for it.  There wasn't much else in the anime as far as music is concerned, but not much felt out of place.  One thing I will mention is the random reiteration of the OP song with a still image of scenery after each time the OP plays.  I've never seen this in an anime, and I still don't quite understand why it existed.  Minor complaint, but odd nonetheless.  I've been flippant when it comes to English voice acting in subbed anime before, and I won't hold my tongue for Rainbow either.  Voicing a white American with an obviously incorrect voice makes me cringe.  Can we stop doing this already?  Those of you that have seen this series will know exactly what I'm talking about.  An aryan guy voiced by a token black actor is just ridiculous.  Ishihara's voice actor deserves an award though, the guy played his part perfectly, and his voice deteriorated at the same rate of Ishihara's own soul.  A job well done.


All in all, I quite enjoyed the experience I had with watching Rainbow Nisha.  I would recommend this anime to just about anyone, especially those fond of atypical or historic genres.  Fans of Kaiji, Baccano or older setting shows would feel right at home with it.  It takes a lot to make me cry in an anime, but Rainbow got me damn close with an important character death.  Man that was hard to watch.  I wish studios would step out on a limb more like with adapting Rainbow and other shows not fitting the current anime stereotypes.  Thanks as always for reading, and be sure to check out my reviews of the Spring 16 anime lineup!

By halfway through, I originally decided to go ahead and mark this one "dropped," but honestly dropping a show like that drives me nuts regardless so I decided to go ahead and finish it. My biggest problem was that the characters and story were all pretty shallow, and seemed to count on some of its shock value type moments to grab the viewer emotionally rather than really building up an emotional attachment. It just felt like "oh, some stuff's happening to some guys," basically. It does improve eventually though, enough that I suppose I don't mind having finished it after all.
I think for the story,there was just too much they tried to pack in to show everybody's individual story. There just wasn't any time to get attached to what was happening.


The art and sound were both good, but not really so much so that I feel there's much else to say about them.


Characters- they just perpetually felt like they were almost good, almost sincere, almost engaging. There were a few scattered moments where I started to think maybe they were finally flushing out better, but it just didn't happen.


I enjoyed a few bits of it, but it definitely wasn't something that I was sad to see end.

It is hard to write a review on a anime with so much within its 26 episodes... but here goes...
The story is amazing, there is deep, momentous very well-paced plot that keeps you clicking on the next episode every time. There is an extraoridinary amount of development with it's plot and a sense of great brotherly love.
The art, is amazing. Since Rainbow (the manga) was written a while ago, there is a look and feel about it characteristic to that era,however, the animators for this series have successfully reinvented it while keeping it true to both the manga and the times, giving it a freshfeel and keeping it remarkably consistent.


The sound is amazing. The opening and closing themes really connect with the viewer and I believe 'wraps' the while feel of the anime.


The characters are one of the great highligts of the anime. Here is where we find the wealth of character development and extraordinary eyeopeners where the journey taken by the main protagonists really lets us have connections and favourites. Really developing each characters individual traits and personalities that lend so much wealth to the show, rather than making another weird psycopathic seinen throwaway anime.


I enjoyed the series, I think that is very apparent from the review and I recommend it to anyone at all, because in truth, this series is a truly heartwarming story of a friendship, love and the conquering of insurmountable odds. 10/10

Seeing there are only biased reviews, I thought I'd actually write about what the anime is like, and not just "Omg, so dark, and it's so good because of it!". It'll be my first review, so please be forgiving.
Story - 7
The story has been pretty predictable from the start, but was still enjoyable until a certain twist at the middle of the series. After that incident, everything went just how one would predict it, so there is no actual suspense or thrill. Every characters get his little arc which always ends with happy end. I must admit, the plot is unique, but the implementation couldbe much better, it had the potential.


Art - 8


Aside from the stiff character designs, the art is pretty good. The background characters don't really move and there are some still images every episode, but overall the art does help us empathizing with the era of the anime. Far from the best work from Madhouse, but the art is still one of the best points of the show.


Sound - 7


There isn't much background musics, so they are overused, and the sound effects are just what you would expect from any other anime. The seiyuus are overall doing a good job, but there are some newbies (like the main character's), whose voices are too stiff and can't really speak with feelings.


Character - 6


There are bad guys and good guys. Bad guys are always ugly, so if you see an ugly guy in the anime, he is bad for sure. Good guys are always good, they don't have any flaws, they always love their buddies over everything else. That's about it. The main characters can be categorized into stereotypes, and there is hardly anything unique about them.


Enjoyment/Overall - 7


Don't be fooled by the unique premise, this is no more than a mediocre show with below par characters and predictable story. As to who I would recommend it to; propably the people who have had enough of the "moe" and "fanservice" shows, and want something "dark", no matter how the anime actually is. I won't say that it's the worst show of the year, but propably the biggest disappointment. For me, at least.

Rainbow: Nisha Rokubo no Shichinin is a historical drama written by Abe George. The anime adaptation was handled by Madhouse with the adaptation writing handled by Takayashiki Hideo. It hasn't been that long since I watched a  Madhouse production, with April's look at One Outs being the last. This is an anime I've never really heard anything about and, given that Madhouse's quality varies significantly, I can't begin to predict how this might rate. We'll just have to take a look and see.  
Story: 
The narrative opens with six men, faces obscured by hoods, being taken on a bus ride with an armedguard. They arrive at a reform school where they're going to be kept locked up for a couple years. They're locked in a cell with another boy named Sakuragi, who they quickly grow to respect. The boys get along, but all is not well. The Reform school has some disturbing secrets that they're going to have to either overcome or learn to survive in spite of. 


I'll start with the negative aspect. Yes, that is negative singular. The story has a narrator. That isn't bad in and of itself, but the problem lies in the execution. Mainly, the narrator doesn't really do anything. You're probably expecting me to give the old “show don't tell” line, but the series does both. The narrator will tell you how a character is feeling after the narrative itself has made that information clear. She'll also summarise plot points that the narrative has either just covered or is about to. As such, the narrator just ends up being redundant and pointless. 


One thing I really appreciate about Rainbow is the handling of dark subject matter. It's all too common for this kind of content to be used for cheap shock value, angst or in an otherwise superficial way by a writer trying to be “mature and edgy” while possessing less maturity than your average twelve year old. In this series, the dark content is uncomfortable and can be very hard to watch because it's handled so well. The series deals with a realistic portrayal of the very worst of humanity and with how to respond to it. I also like that the characters don't find easy resolutions. Instead, they deal with these situations as best as they can and, sometimes, they fail in spite of it. When a new problem comes up you never know if the resolution is going to be tragic, bittersweet, or triumphant but you can count on it having verisimilitude. The uncertainty does help the story stay compelling. I also like the way the narrative flows. It progresses very naturally from one situation to the next while giving you ample time to adjust and wind down before entering into the next conflict. 


Characters: 


The characters in this are superlative. The main characters are all good people, but far from perfect. They falter. They make mistakes and they do things that they shouldn't. Their mistakes and problems all make sense for their characters, which makes the conflicts resulting from them feel very natural. They're complex characters who develop and grow throughout the series. It never feels forced nor contrived.  Even the antagonists feel like actual people. Terrible people mind you, but not exaggeratedly evil or cartoonish. The character interactions are spectacular. The seven main protagonists have a really strong camaraderie dynamic and they play off of each other very strongly.  


I do like that the main characters never cross the moral line. They do some things that are  illegal, but it's always understandable. Sometimes, it's even the right thing to do. At their very worst, their actions are well intentioned but misguided which does happen to good, moral people quite frequently. 


Art: 

The art  is very good with some nice details and memorable character designs. The creepy scenes with dark content are animated in a way that highlights how horrible what's happening is. The biggest problem with it is the strange coloured effect they like to use during freeze frames. It would work well if they used it rarely for emphasis, but it pops up far too much for it to work in that capacity. Consequently, it quickly starts to feel like a measure to save on the animation budget instead of like an aspect that's doing something. 


Sound: 


The vocal cast is stellar. Our seven protagonists are played by Paku Romi, Koyama Rikiya, Fujiwara Keiji, Kuroda Takaya, Hasome Tatsuya, Oguri Shun & Waki Tomohiro. The last three of whom I have not heard in much, if anything, aside from this. All of them do deliver very strong performances. As do the minor and secondary characters. This is also one of the few times I've seen an anime where they have American characters speak English with an American accent. Usually when you have characters who are supposedly foreign they still have pronounced Japanese accents. 


The music is pretty good. Most of the time it's barely noticeable, fading into the background. The big exceptions are moments that are quiet otherwise and the scenes where Jou sings. The music does work well for those moments. 


Ho-Yay: 


Rainbow does touch on homosexuality, primarily with one of the antagonists who does not buy into the idea of consent. You could probably read it into some of the relationships among the main seven as well, but I really see their dynamics as more of a strong camaraderie. So, the ho-yay factor is a 3/10. 


Final Thoughts: 


Rainbow: Nisha Rokubo no Shichinin is an excellent series. It's a complex work that handles dark content maturely, which is sadly rare with dark works. The cast is excellent, both in terms of characters and vocally. The biggest problem with the series is the pointless narrator and it's really not a huge issue. That being said, it does have some very chilling depictions of sexual abuse and violence. If that's going to be triggering or hugely upsetting for you, you're probably going to want to steer clear. My final rating is going to be a 9/10. Next week, get your popcorn ready. It's time for films.

We as Americans have a different sort of drama preference. And of all these preferences, there is one that sticks to my mind. Shawshank Redemption, Prison Break, Green Mile, all these fantastic dramas have one thing in common: prison. Prison is naturally going to pull American viewers in, but why, I don't know. Perhaps its the despair people feel when they are stripped of everything, even their dignity, and how they struggle to survive in their hostile environment. Or maybe its the strong bonds created through prisoners holding on to hope by sharing it with prisoners who understand the pain and sorrow. Whatever the casemay be, Rainbow is nothing short of a great prison drama.


The story follows six youths sent to prison for multiple different reasons. After being violated by the prison doctor Dr. Sasaki and assulated by the psychotic guard Ishihara, they are thrown into a prison sell with a man named Sakaragi. After picking a fight with him and epic-ly losing, Sakaragi and the boys begin to build an unbreakable bond as they struggle to survive, since underneath the surface a horrible secret is being kept by Dr. Sasaki and Ishihara that Sakaragi knows, and if they let him escape alive it would them who are prison. The story is quite graphic and harsh, and may take a mature person to watch. Other than that, the story does wonders in the drama category providing very touching moments as well as tragic. However, every dram should have comic relief, and although Rainbow has it, its very minimal in comparison to the point where it becomes very depressing. This is not a big deal, however, since its so dramatic. Now, the show slows down a little early in the second half, but this doesn't mean it lacks any nice moments.


The art is very nice and has an old-fashioned feel to it for me. Its very clean and simple, and dark tones are used throughout in order to intensify the "darkness" of the story.


The soundtrack was a bit weird for me. The BGMs were the main reason. It didn't really match with the story for me, and although they were nice by themselves, for some reason it ruined the mood for me. HOWEVER, the OP and ED are a completely different story. The OP was badass, and during the chorus you instantly get a feel of sorrow and almost a foreshadowing of what's to come. The ED sends you off in a way that says that they are "never givin' up", and the vocals themselves leave a singer like me pissed off for being as sucky as I am.


The characters are phenomenal. Each character (except for Soldier...) has a big part somewhere in the show, and back stories are explained nicely. Honestly, there isn't anything to complain about, it was a superb job.


This show is a personal favorite of mine is a must-see for drama seekers looking for a different kind of drama. Rainbow pulls the curtain off a hidden reality of crudeness and evil in the world, and how, ironically, the young men in prison struggle against it despite their differences in power and wealth. Its truly a great show, and I highly recommend it.

What exactly is friendship? Are your friends more important to you than your family? What are you willing to go through for a friend? Rainbow: Nisha Rokubou no Shichinin (for the rest of the review the anime will be referred to simply as Rainbow) focuses on friendship, as well as several other themes based around friendship, such as humanity, morality, violence, love, family etc. This is my review:
Story - Rainbow is a tale about seven inmates in a special reform school who grow closer with the increased time they spend together. All seven of them are there for committing several crimes which shaped these verydifferent yet very similar individuals. From the opening moments of the first episode right through to the last scene of the last episode I was hooked. The show grabbed me and forced me to sit down and watch what happened next. Rainbow is brutal, mature, dark and at times depressing. But I was surprised at how light the show can get at certain points, from the funny banter between the seven inmates to the way they overcome obstacles by relying on each other and their bond. The tone shifts from time to time but Rainbow manages to keep the shifts fluid and smooth. For me, Rainbow had two highlights, and the story was definitely one of them. The writing was well done because the show didn't come off as melodramatic and managed to feel really inspirational at certain points and there were more twists than one would expect from a show like this.


Characters - I mentioned that the show had two aspects that really stood out. The characters were the second aspect.  These were really cool guys. They were bad ass but they were portrayed in such a sympathetic way that you would root for all of them, sort of like multi-layered anti-heroes. The story was really amazing but I really enjoyed seeing the guys react to the situations they found themselves in. Character driven stories always work when it's executed properly. Like I said their friendship is an intricate part of the story. It is tested time and time again. It's wonderful to see selfless friendship like the one showed here. If you have a best friend or an entire "entourage" that you'll take a bullet for you'll know what I'm talking about. Two characters took a back seat to the others sometimes but that didn't detract from how enjoyable Rainbow was.


Sound - The voice acting was fantastic with each character sounding like they ought to. It is a lot more difficult to illustrate chemistry between animated characters than live-action characters but once again Rainbow manages to pull it off. There are a couple of bonuses available in the form of short clips with some the show's shows voice actors  and I must say I really found new respect for seiyuus. The OP is probably not for everyone. A heavy metal track will turn some off but in my opinion it fitted well with the tone and atmosphere of the show. Listen to it and you'll know what to expect. The rest of the OST wasn't very bad and after listening to "A FAR OFF DISTANCE" I just had to get it on my phone.


Art - Rainbow's art is really good. I'm not an artist so I don't know how to explain it in detail but it's not too shabby. The art is very realistic like seinen should be. There are no alterations to characters' facial expressions for Japanese slapstick and like the voice acting, the art of each inmate fits to their personality and who they are.


Enjoyment - A part of me wishes that I didn't see Rainbow because after watching it, it'll be hard to find another series that will be able to top the standard Rainbow set. The story is brutal and violent, but also sincere and inspirational. The characters are extremely likeable and their relationship can get one emotional. Lump in throat emotional. The voice acting and soundtrack sound great and the art is beautiful. George Abe and Masumi Kakizaki really managed to create a distinctive style here.


Rainbow is a fantastic character driven story chronicling the lives of seven inmates who became best friends. The show is not for the weak of heart but please give it a try, you'll be surprised how much you love it. 


10/10


Who said anime was just for kids?

This is not the kind of anime you watch to enjoy and have a great time, let me just start with that.
This is the kind of anime which I have to stop watching every 2 episodes or else I'll punch holes in my walls, this is the kind of anime that makes me hate humans, that makes me want to vomit and makes me wish that certain people would just drop dead. 
It is the kind of anime that reminds me what it means to have friends whom you can trust and depend on and how important it is to stay true to yourself, itreminds me that no matter how bad things may look life goes on and it will get better eventually, it also makes me take a serious look at my own life and what I can do to affect those around me.\n\n
This is an anime I highly recommend watching, not for enjoyment or having a laugh but for an important life-lesson.\n\n
Even if this is just another anime it is important to remember that those situations are still very real to many people all over the world, if you watch/have watched this anime and thought even once that something is seriously wrong with this world then please take a moment to reflect upon what you can do to change it, anything is fine even if it's just being extra helpful and considerate to the people around you, if enough people do this we might eventually get to the point where violence, rape, killing, torture and other nasty stuff only happens in fiction, as it SHOULD be, so please, if you have read this then consider what you want to accomplish in life, remember that your own mindset can play an important role in the future, you might not be able to do something alone but if you keep inspiring people to take action you might actually be able to change the world.

[Remake review]
Rainbow is one of those animes that are considered devalued or "cult". For not having moeshit, school or anything. The scene in which rainbow is happening, is a scenario not very common animes, and for this reason did not call so much attention. But such an anime in my view should have been popular because the anime is edgy and has a lot of violence, psychopathic / one-dimensional villains. These are things that makes it a popular title, but for some reason this anime has been forgotten or devalued.
Now let's talk about the story of rainbow: The story of rainbow is simply shit. Thenarrative is very slow, and it begins by making mistakes. Like for example: To give flashbacks to its characters in the first episodes, being these flashbacks very exaggerated and forced. It's the usual cheap emotional manipulation ever. But believe me, it gets much worse. The more we advance, the more we discover that conflict and drama are pathetic. Conflict is unilatreal in black and white. On one side we have the characters super cute and pacifists, on the other side the super bad psychopaths. It is a kind of childish and pathetic plot. You believe all the drama is idiot edgy, because all the drama of this shit is basically torture and misery, and end. And the worst thing is that this drama would be non-existent if the characters used their fists on the psychopathic villains, but no. They prefer to be tortured because they are a saint and a complete idiot. It is because of this stupidity of these characters that one of the characters died. And what makes the anime even more childish, is its dialogues. The dialogues are just awful. Most of the dialogues are those typical friendship speeches of any shounen.


And that's it. Rainbow is basically this. Torture and misery of characters who are a saint vs. psychopathic villains who live by abusing them. There is nothing special about this story. It's just victimization and forced drama, with characters without much personality that only has flashbacks.


The only thing to praise in this anime are the production values. The production values ​​are very mature. The atmosphere is very appropriate. and focus on the total in that. Without getting you down with comedy slapstick or other generic shit. Otherwise, it's a pathetic and edgy story with absolutely nothing special, besides being very boring, childish and edgy.


Torture has never been a good drama, stop it. Please

An unbelievably touching, feel-wrecking, gripping anime. Rainbow is amazingly well done, scenes are perfect, the art is very colorful and detailed, the Characters are all unbelievably deep and there´s practically an arc for each one, the animation is very fitting, fluid and realistic, the storyline is never boring, the amazing moments give me goosebumps everytime. This anime is definitely a masterpiece. I´d say it´s even better than steins;gate but Steins;gate is still my Number 1, only because Rainbow doesn´t hype me just as much. Otherwise, this  would be at #1. This seemingly neverending tragic story, the beautiful friendship of the main characters, the really"fucked up" moments even, the courage and fighting spirit that all of the characters show and the amazing moral and wiseness this story brings make this anime truly spectacular. Story:          
          This series is a mixture of shounen and seinen. The story is about 6 teen boys that are brought into a prison-like disciplinary school where they meet Sakuragi Rokurota, a boy year or two older than them. And with Sakuragi's help who they call "bro" their inner core will come to light and turn them into solid men. It has a lot of comical parts, action and struggle. But everything is done in convincing and realistic approach. 
Art:The Graphics are not really striking but not so bad (The villains are really ugly!). There are times that the character's appearances are not consistent. However, The scenery, backgrounds, and the general time setting the story occurs in was shown as you would have imagined it during the war era. 


Sound/Music

          There is lot of good music throughout the anime. I really like the song “Dear Night Rainbow”. The music corresponds with the dramatic scene. (That scene really made me cry). The japanese dub is very well made and features voice actors such as Romi Paku, Fujiwara Keiji and Oguri Shun who all did an impressive work on their characters and conveyed out their temperament even further. The narrator though is kinda lacking.


Characters:


           The characters are all interesting. The main characters have resilient and distinct traits, with quite a bit of character progress and background. The minor characters are equally plausible.


Overall


         I really enjoyed this anime. It's a powerful story that shows great friendship and sacrifice. a mature story that is both harsh and idealistic


Note: The anime covered only 100 chapters of the Manga.

THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS
Rainbow: Nisha Rokubou no Shichinin is often described as realistic, dark or even deep. It’s none of that. This is a show heavily driven by an unrealistic bond of friendship that wasn’t properly formed, but still exists. The writing isn’t smart, don’t expect a story that keeps you at the edge of your seat, but enjoy a tale of friends trying to bounce up when life wants them to stay down. 
 Tldr, this has so many plot holes and thoughtlessly handled situations that could of easily been avoided, but I really enjoyed the slice of life aspect of the show. Goodcharacters, development was well done. Really enjoyable series despite it’s thoughtless advances. Soundtrack is amazing, now up there with my favorite anime soundtracks. Aesthetics were good, nothing to complain, but also nothing to praise. 


After watching a scene I usually write some thoughts down about it, if I have any. I tried to format them into a review as best as I could. This isn’t a recommendation so if you haven’t seen the anime and are still reading them please don’t, I go into detail about the anime so I will spoil it for you. 


MASSIVE SPOILERS BEYOND THIS. 


Joe committed a crime so his voice doesn’t hold much credibility, but is that enough to cover up the way he was treated by the foster lady. Not only did she break a vase in his face, but almost stabbed him, while he accused her of molesting him. And this all happened in front of authorities too. Why was nothing done to her. In one hand, the inmates are framed as the ugliest of criminals who’ve committed the worst things imaginable, you’d ought to put these highly dangerous scums of earth in a secure place where they can be properly conducted. Even so, their system is a joke. The guards, get away with so much crap despite how powerless they act at times. 


When the Ishihara tells Uncovered that Sakuragi was in there for killing his own parents Uncovered wasted no time to react, immediately making a scene without questioning anything. Uncovered seems to be the reserved type, he doesn't want to get attached to the group, but he's also supposed to be the 'smart' one, not very smart of him to be impulsive instead of being reasonable. Later on in the episode he tells Sakuragi that he's sick of being in the same room as him, why so much hostility towards someone he barely knows. The irony in all this is how Uncovered, who babbles so much hatred towards people for being selfish, becomes what he hates the most, a selfish scum who sells out good people that bothered to show interest in him only to save himself from a beating. Irony truly is a gift.  


Now we know why Sakuragi is in the reformatory school. He goes into further detail with the nurse "My... father died... At my hands. I... killed him." Quoted from the subs. But wait, in the flashback, never once did he lay a hand on his father, who committed suicide. Even though prior to this episode,  Ishihara tells Uncovered the reason Sakuragi is in there was because he killed his own parents. Now you can say Ishihara twisted his words in order to get Uncovered to hate Sakuragi, but how are we supposed to know he was doing that? So when hearing he killed his own parents, I thought maybe his parents were scumbags so their murder will be justified, but he DIDN'T kill his father, he just feels responsible. His ability to put himself in his father's perspective sprinkles a little growth to his character. He understood his father's guilt for surviving a war that had killed five of his sons. He understood how tough it was to find work at the time. He understood how difficult it must of been to blend into a new society. He now understood his father's suffering, but it was too late. A bit melodramatic, but serves a point so I'll take it.


I think this anime is interesting so I've been trying to ignore how easily they became the best of buddies, but the show makes it really hard with all the exaggerated friendship moments. 


Some people may not agree, but I think Ishihara-Sasaki duo calls for some properly written villains. The corrupt Ishihara who sells prisoners in exchange for money and the perverted doctor who rapes them. They depict a selfish nature that unfortunately exists in our world, corrupted law enforcement in Mexico is quite common and just a couple weeks ago a doctor was convicted of abuse on over a hundred cases. While I do think the writers could of done better, they did enough to justify the harsh treatment they are giving Sakuragi. This shines a more humane emotion, at least towards Ishihara, fear. The fear of losing power and credibility he's earned himself. The fear of a cold, terrorizing glare of an inmate. He's not invincible and he knows that, this draws forth the agony of Sakuragi being released and ruining him. Initially I thought this all fell apart when Ishihara begins injecting himself with drugs and becomes insane. But after looking back, it kinda makes sense. See, Sakuragi promises Ishihara one day he will make him wish he was dead towards the beginning of the show, this was because Ishihara caused his friend to kill himself and Sakuragi most likely wanted to avenge his good pal. Ishihara is driven insane by this promise, starts pumping drugs into himself (probably in order to distract him from his fear of Sakuragi) and wishing Sakuragi would just kill him once and for all. Sakuragi fulfilled his promise! Cheeky bastard. 


Now for the biggest cuck, Sakuragi’s death. ecksfuckingdee bois. I didn't really care for Sakuragi much tbh. He didn't stand-out as anything unique in anyway. So I’m not even being biased about them killing him off. Surely my anger is justified when the idiot gets himself killed. Now I'm a nice guy, I can look passed him giving the demented Ishihara the letter despite it being the only leverage they have to keep the guys still inside jail safe. He also didn't kill him even when he was stabbed, ok I'm still chill. Now the idiot keeps on walking when he is ordered to stay still. The good guys of nippon telling him it's for his own benefit to stay down since he is bleeding out, then the big bad americanos come and shred the guy to pieces BECAUSE HE WOULDN'T STAY STILL. LOL! Why didn't he stop! Was he bleeding out so badly he couldn't think straight anymore? I need something other than he wanted to see Mario win, what a big fucking joke. Also why was he even in the reformatory school? He didn’t kill his parents, plot hole. 


Happy to say, the show picks itself up a bit in the second half. Just a little. 


Sakuragi's death proves itself a necessity to the plot. Without it there would only be a cycle of cat and mouse between Ishihara/Sasaki and the gang; mainly towards Sakuragi. Still can't forgive the thoughtless way they killed him though. 


Queue the overused black and white scene:

Some drunk guy's being a drunk guy trying to get out of paying his tab on the bar, harassing the poor defenseless bartender. Time for Mario to show us his heroic skills. He gives the guy two free hits and then kicks his ass, I wonder where this forced scene will take us. OH, the drunk guy's back with the cops! Mario's busted bois. It's not like the drunk guy deserved it for 1. being drunk, 2. Assaulting the bartender, 3. Hitting Mario first, TWICE. But you know, Mario still has to take the bullet for it to move the plot along. It’s jail time bois, get the soap ready. Naw dawg, this show isn’t having that, which is a good thing, they did a good thing. I’d have a hard time enjoying the show if they basically repeated the first half of the show again. They didn’t though, they moved on to more mundane human affairs, this is where the show begins to entertain me.  


Soldier shows intelligence, he shows determination. He had a goal that he worked towards and learned from it. He was even able to get out of the school earlier because of this. Same goes for Uncovered, but we already knew that from the way they perfectly handled him towards the beginning of the show.


"This guy's the biggest dumbass in all of Japan..." - Soldier 


Uncovered is all about the irony, again. I love this guy! We've all seen it before, the smart guy falls in love for the chick who's only toying with him. The show wastes no effort in letting it's audience know what's going on, as the above quote reads, Soldier calls him an idiot while he beats the shit outta him. Now again, props to Soldier for taking action in such a way; I know I'd wanna punch him for spending the money he borrowed from me like that. To me, it's not about using cliches or not, but how you present them. In the end, Uncovered wasn't angry at her, he wasn't sad he was played with. He couldn't feel sad, he knew nothing about her, it was nothing personal. He put himself in her perspective, it must of been horrible for her to be unable to ever find happiness. And it really must be horrible, that's something anyone can relate to.


God, that last episode was so fucking beautiful. Boxing was a big theme in this show, Sakuragi did a number on all six at their first encounter cause he was a boxer, this introduces Mario to boxing. It also played the stupid role in getting Sakuragi killed. Now Mario, the successor of Sakuragi, stands in the ring with all his friends watching, as well as the side characters that appeared throughout the show (we missed Setsuko unfortunately). Then the tree scene, which even though we all knew what his wish was, still provides enough closure. 


The show had many small arcs, which are also properly paced,  I give this props. They could of just played cat and mouse as I've said before, but no. Instead they played with different scenarios each time with another character in focus, sometimes things went their way, sometimes they didn't. There is no overpowered foe that comes back again and again, each time invincibly stronger. The hardest part is over in the first half, now outside of the reformatory school they are free men, who are trying to do something with their lives. I wish a little more screen time would of been dropped on Soldier which, to me, showed the most promise, but oh well.

Rainbow:Nisha Rokubou no Shichinin! Anime  and a story that shouldn't be ignored! if you are hesitating do not be, because this anime is a masterpiece! why? let's review it step by step!

Anime is based on friendship and hardworking,how you can not be self-centered and be a MAN in all senses. the main Hero Sakuragi is your big bro who teaches everything you need not to be a kid.this show makes you want to reconsider your everyday routine and change immediately.animation's might not be the best but who cares, this story has so much variety and spectrum that you will be stunned after ep1.


I would talk a lot more about this anime for hours but words can't describe how amazing this is and it is a shame I did not watch this earlier. ANCHAN you are our hero! bravo to the writer.Joe, Mario, Suppon, Baremoto, Heitai and Kyabetsu I will never forget about you guys!

i'm done with this title and i'm a bit perplexed about it, and by that i mean how to feel about this series.
i'm gonna be blunt, i've seen a lot of 10/10s for rainbow so this time i'm taking it upon myself to bring a more realistic & logical view on it because in this title's case, you can't really depend on most of the mal or rainbow's fan group to convey a significant outlook on a series if they base their experience only on enjoyment and a bunch of cool guys.
this one could've well been a masterpiece and it's because of the concept first& foremost. six guys, different backgrounds, they share the 2-6 cell and they get close to the guy who would soon become the best of friends. seven of them, enduring brutal suffering and humiliation by the corrupt people of the facility. will they make it through their time there and what kind of life awaits them on the other side?


this is a show that i randomly stumbled upon because i was looking what to see next, and the premise of it got to me. i'll describe the positives before the negatives.


storytelling. it had a narrative approach to it but in the way that could actually immerse you into the world of rainbow, it felt lowkey personal at times but this could vary from person to person. music, great ost, very memorable in general. it really doesn't miss its mark. animation. animation has come a long way through time and i've learned to appreciate all styles and depths of it. this one was made by madhouse, and they really knew what they were doing with this one. but it isn't just about how it looks, it's about how well it fits with the nature of a series like this, that you don't really see often, an anime centered mostly in prison, about the guys from that prison.

the characters. the plot of rainbow is mainly character-driven, so they're basically the core of the series. there is meaning to each one of the seven's character aside from only their personalities, hence why the series is named rainbow. but what does that make sakuragi, the actual heaven? that's at least how i deal with this though.


the bad parts. this show takes itself way too seriously which leads to over-emotion. it's just too emotional at times when it doesn't need to be, and by this i'm taking a fully logical & realistic approach to it. it's really not that serious sometimes.


second. i'll tell you the reason why this title has such a high mean score. it's because some cool guys befriended another cool guy and their bond became impenetrable through events that follow. rainbow focuses way too much on the main cast, making it cool & appealable that it forgets about other things.


the pacing is rather displeasing. because how are you gonna lump 6 strangers in a prison cell with another guy and they suddenly become like a family in a day or two? it doesn't work like that. things happen way too fast and leave you with questions that will never get answered. the second half was decent though.


there is too much importance put on ONLY the main cast that the side events or even characters just lack any form of logic behind them. that goes for the first half though. if you don't pay attention it won't be immediately obvious to you but it's an absolute turn-off having to watch the side events unfold with some half-assed logic and sometimes the price that has to be paid with it takes a monumental shift with the mood of the series & the actual plotline.


overall, this was at least an above average or fine experience, summing up my enjoyment factor, how much this series wants to appeal to you, especially because it's a seinen and my assessment of concept & quality-control. and that's the kind of score i'm giving it.

This show is a tease, with bait so delectable that you can't think twice when you dive for it. You have 6 mysterious characters who have caused some sort of mayhem to be sent to prison. Are some of the characters wrongfully accused? Are some of them actual madmen? You have this dark setting to go along with scenes that are mostly visual, the animation tells the story. I was thinking to myself how brilliant it was, the possibilities of what they could do. Then 15 minutes passed, and, review below
 The 6, which is now 7 characters are good guys. Not Protagonists, butgood guys, meaning they will risk their lives for anything at the drop of hat in a 5 second encounter with a stranger . I was expecting the main guys to be more dimensional, some would be cowards, some are desperate scum, one could actually have a lust for hurting others, and one could be generic nice guy that realizes reality isn't as kind. However, everything in this show is black and white. 


The 7 of them form an immediate bonding friendship for life, and the thought of characters learning about each other is sort of ruined by the narrator. This show is just 20 minutes of Bro! Bro! Anchan! Bro! Anchan! With all of their crimes being justified by how overly cruel their obstacle was. The "Survival of the fittest," motto they shoved at us was nulled by their friendship, and for some reason most of the episodes take place after their prison release. 7 characters in prison? That's enough material for 26 episodes.


Story-


Not bad, 7 people in prison that must deal with all the cruelty that comes.


Art- 


Very grainy, dark, and somewhat detailed. Not bad for what the show was going for, or trying to go for


Sound-


Not much music, which is sometimes good. Great for this show, but the few songs were very intense sounding, and not to my taste.


Characters-


These characters are very boring. They don't offer anything new or creative, and in this kind of setting, that's where most of the focus should have been on. How they deal with their new life, and mostly, each other. But we're granted with preachy, goody kids that were just in a pickle of a situation, and made a mistake. A mistake the anime tries to justify so hard. It's like if someone stole an apple for his starving village that's about to be flooded. Some characters can be nicety nice nice, but there should have been more variety. Have some depth, and insight on pathetic scum who would abandon people to save self or others who just enjoy causing others pain. It's a lot more interesting then mindless Yugioh friendship drones. 


Oh the villain is my favorite character. They made them as ugly, sinister, creepy, and crazy as possible. I wouldn't be surprised if they gave them razor sharp teeth, and nervous twitches oh wait. In most cases, these villains would be very boring, but they're so over the top that it seems like a parody. One of them is the prison doctor who gets his sexual desires out of alien probing younger kids. The other is an asshole, because he's an asshole, and that's it. That's the villain, no second thought if it's actually the warden or the inmates who are good. Very black, and white. The characters, and their actions could have been more controversial. Bro! Anchan!


Enjoyment-


I did not enjoy it as much as I wanted. Not the worse. The shock value flash backs in it were indeed shocking. And it's just so interesting on how crazy the warden is. Aside from the good guys, it was ok.


Overall-


This show is below most shounen. Even Naruto for a time went to a grey route, and showed that justice is in the eyes of the beholder. Good, and Evil all comes down to how the individual feels. Those shows, however, can get away with being bland, and preachy, because that's just how shounen animes are. Not to mention they're in a fantasy world where things run differently.


I'm not 100% sure what Rainbow was going for, but if it was trying to give us a look on life back then, it didn't pick the right people.

I'll start saying that I chose this series as my personal project in my fansub group; each admin had its share and I picked up Rainbow. I had never saw anything about it neither read the manga, but the sinopsis and the promotional pic hooked me up immediately. The 2010 april season was full of "pink" anime and Rainbow looked like some serious "blue" matter; and since I'm a huge fan of shounen, I couldn't lose this opportunity to introduce some "manliness" into my team mates and followers.
Right before start the translation process, I picked up the first three manga episodes and read them ina rush: I died! Not only the story was raw and cruel, the things that characters had to suffer touched my heart. There I remember I thought "My gosh, I could have done a great choice this time".



Story: 9/10

The story's premise is simple: six teenagers, all of them involved in some criminal action (generally, because very good or desperate reasons), are imprisoned into Shounen Reformatory, a juvenile prison full of injustices and abuses. There, the self-centered boys meet their senpai, a guy older than them that has been imprisoned for a whole year by now. He teaches them a lesson since he considers them as "a bunch of monkeys", and then the kids fall in love with this guy. He becomes their light in that dark path, and even after they leave the facility he continues illuminating their lives. The story can be divided into two different arcs: the first 12 episodes inside the facility, and 14-26 which portrays their lives outside.


What made this story so special to me was the rawness of the things they have to stand and the strenght every character depicts once they understand what camaraderie is truly about. Also, the feeling you have in some parts of the story is certainly creepy: when you start to think these kids can't be more disgraceful, something even worse happens to them. The reformatory's pests, the very nasty doctor Sasaki and his henchman the guard Ishihara, makes boys' lives a living hell; but they manage to survive to live after through the most important thing they learn in prison: the bond of friendship.


What I disliked of this anime is the speed that sometimes risks to ruin it all. Some characters are not explored as much as others and you can get the feeling that they didn't have any development. Since they're quickly introduced to you, you can guess which kind of personality each one have. That could have been better, I like to discover characters while the story's going on. Some plots were easy to guess too, in counterpart to the well-planned others.



Art: 9/10

The animation is one of the best I've seen. The high contrast between the dark scenes in the reformatory and the "pure air" you can breath in the outside world really makes you feel the difference between one and another. The use of static scenes, with textured, alternative colours, was one of the big achievements, it gets you some strange feeling. You can think and consider the action scene you just seen with this "stop" pics.

The character design is something I liked very much. They're not highly handsome boys, even girls are not exaggeratedly pretty and don't even mention villains, they're all quite disgusting, but that helped to keep the anime into a "normal" state of things. It helped me to keep the characters into a realistic view. The animation is sublime and goes very well with the design.



Sound: 10/10

This is an absolute. The BGM has to be one of the most accurated I've had the pleasure to listen. Every song has its moment and they transmit a very particular feeling. The voices are great. Every character has personality and mood swings, pretty real mood swings. The best work in my opinion goes for Rikiya Koyama, seiyuu for An-chan, and Shun Oguri as Mario.

The opening is brutal, an awesome way to start every episode; the ending has been made to get you all cheesy, because when the episode ends, you want to cry just because of the song! 



Character: 9/10

Rokurota, or An-chan, is far away the best character of the whole bunch. A young, troubled man who has learnt to live looking forward, a character with a huge heart and street wisedom that fights every single day to find a bit of happiness in this dark world. He's pretty well developed and is easy to feel him as a natural leader while he guides the boys through that dark path.


Mario is a character that also developes himself very satisfactorily. He starts as the others, a punk with nothing to live for, but in the end you have realized, as you walk this difficult path beside him, that he's the most sweet, kind boy of all.


Noboru (Turtle/Suppon) is a tiny thing, a very irritating kid that finds himself through hard lessons. Another success among the characters.


Ryuuji (Uncovered/Baremoto) is perhaps the most predictable of them. He's very selfish and greedy and makes a lot of mistakes during the series, but also has a good heart and it makes up for it.


Tadayoshi (Soldier/Heitai) was and is my personal favourite among the six boys, and I'm frankly disappointed because he didn't had his spot. His crime, life and personality are easy to guess, but I'd certainly liked to learn a little bit more from him.


Mansaku (Cabbage) is the classic friendly giant; I'm sure his crime was made because a very stupid mistake. He earns your heart with his calm mood and kindness.


Jyou (Joe) is the pretty boy. I was afraid to see him develop into some kind of predictable crybaby, but in the end proved to be the rudest of all and the most crazy kamikaze.


In the end, I was pretty satisfied with every character (even the supporting ones, they have crappy lives also), except the mentioned Soldier's abstinence. The northamericans portrayed in this series are kinda weird, a bit forced, but they fulfill their duty: as the "enemies", the boys learn to see them as persons as well.



Enjoyment: 10/10

I found myself enjoying every single episode. None of them left me with a disappointment feeling: in exchange, I died to see the next. I dropped tears of joy and sorrow with every trial the kids had to overcome, with every reunion, with every tragedy. Despite of the mentioned predictable plots, the resolution of each conflict touched my heart in a powerful, strong way. It moved me into tears more than once.



Overall: 10/10

Though I've written the few things I disliked, I can't give this series a lower rating. It just won a place in my heart in its entire form. I loved every single piece of it, even the mistakes or the predictable stuff, because the teaching it gives to you is so moving that I feel I didn't waste my time watching it: the lesson of friendship, the lesson of hope, all of that prepacked with an exciting old-school flavour and, more importantly, manly tears!!

''What is  life without happiness?'' -Rokurota Sakuragi
Rainbow is a story of friendship. How friendship can grow through hardship in an era  were everything was going wrong.  This is rainbow. A heartwarming,sad,  but at the same time an optimistic anime about life. Rainbow as a story was really good made and developed. Although at the time you are watching it you will say at specific times that the story can't go on, the anime continues in a magical way where the story won't get exaggerated or dull. Rainbow's story had only two flaws. First of all they should have one story atleast for Soldier as he was the only character that he didn't have his own story arc. Yet he was my favorite character. Also with the exception of Joe, Turtle and Sakuragi we didn't learn anyone else background story. And it was a pity really because it would be really interesting. But overall rainbow is an anime that displays friendship in a harsh time were a good friend was the most important thing in the world and it manages to display it really good.\n
In the animation department I have to say one thing: Madhouse. So yeah enough said I believe.\n
The sound was also amazing.  The opening was a song performed by Coldrain a famous Japanese rock band and it had a really deep meaning about the anime. The ending was performed by Galneryus one of my favorite Japanese bands and even though I don't like so much their ballads it was a heartwarming song that left you with a bittersweet feeling every time an episode ended.\n
And now for the characters. In one word they were amazing. From Mario and Joe to Cabbage and Soldier every person in this anime had their own problems and demons inside them. But no matter what they have to deal with, their friendship was the most important thing for them. You will see huge character development from the time that the kids are inside the prison but also the time after they came out of there. From he start until the end the anime was built solely on character development.\n
So what is friendship? And how far would you go for your friend? This is the question that rainbow asks. This anime made me laugh, cry, love, hate and live through its characters. Sometimes it may drug it's story a lot but then it will regain your interest again with it's adorable characters. It's a unique anime way different from what we are used to. A must watch for me. Hope they would made more anime like this.
