*Spoiler Free*
After reading the synopsis, I was immediately interested and the reviews seemed to be popping out with excellent scores. This story is an immediate 10/10 for many reasons. Quick overview: The storyline and characters are so deep and compelling that it just has to be a 10/10. Watch this anime, you won't regret it.
Firstly what is this story about: Simple, it's about a bond shared between 7 cellmates in a reformatory prison. This story goes so in depth that this bond surpasses any other "bro-ship" you can think of (even the one between Bulat and Tatsumi in akame ga kill). The things these sevenmen are willing to do for each other will warm the hearts of anyone and everyone.


Story: 6 teens are sent to a reformatory prison due to their own crimes (most involved stealing or violence). Though the reformatory prison is very much so "Hell on Earth" the 6 boys manage to meet another cellmate who would change their lives for the ever:Rokurouta Sakuragi (AKA BRO-CHAN).


The storyline is so intense and deep that you'll have no other choice but to watch the next episode. 


Character: Each has their own sad past, leaving the viewers pitying them for growing up in hellish conditions. Only negative of the anime is that they didn't go into depth about two certain character's passed but nevertheless you are still shown hints of their past in the O.P. The antagonists in this anime are so evil and detailed that you'll be leaving them on your top 10 antagonist list.


Sound: A 10/10. The opening fits perfectly with the theme and the anime's title. Secondly, there are times when Americans will be talking in English and it sounds normal. I've watched so many animes where the English of Non-Japanese and Japanese anime characters has been so cringe-worthy.

Wow talk about finding a hidden gem this is really one of those Animes that you watch on a gamble or maybe you saw some good reviews but can't seem to find a lot about it through word of mouth from friends because chances are it's probably overwhelmed by all the other great shows out there or maybe just the synopsis alone is so unique that it's hard to determine whether it's worth a shot or not...
But honestly this is one anime that will really stick with you... Not through "shock and awe" or cliche anime/story tropes we've seen countless times may they be goodor bad...


This anime is really one strap yourself in and buckle up for something you really won't expect!


26 episodes and this anime will switch gears on you fast and hard it honestly has everything you would want from action, romance, heartbreak, friendship, betrayal, anything you can think of it's got it!


Some people may complain around the 15 episode mark or so the anime WILL switch gears but like I said but there is a purpose for it... and believe me the final episode of this Anime... Will leave you the most SATISFIED you have ever felt about any Anime you have ever watched... 


When the ride ends there will be no looking back... Just the feeling of knowing this is something you will never forget I know I won't.

For those people looking for a realistic anime that has to do with the struggles in life, and something motivational then this is the anime for you. This anime was amazing.
The story follows 6 young men who get sent to jail based on their reasons and mistakes from the past because of the hard times they lived through. It's based after the war in japan. The characters follow a man they meet in Jail as their cellmate and learn that they should follow their dreams even if they are being threatened. They face life's hardest challenges and even death. The art was great for it'stime. The music and soundtrack was great and greatly went with the mood and theme of the show. There was great character development for only 24 episodes shown. I greatly enjoyed the show, like literally I was hooked. Overall it was an amazing show and I recommend it to anybody over the age of 14 because there are some disturbing parts because it's so realistic.

Rainbow Nisha an anime without a doubt that i will never forget and that in its time i did not and now I regret it because I did not see before, an anime with a beautiful message of incredible life all narrated in a history quite crude and cruel where show the suffering of 7 guys prisoners at the end of the second world war and how they are at the mercy of the greed lust and the desire of the adults in a cruel world in which will be able to survive thanks to the unwavering loop of your friendship, an anime where thecharacters without doubt will suffer greatly and open many difficulties on the path toward happiness, but there is always a light at the end Of the tunnel, the music the characters animation everything is perfect in this gem of FOR MADHOUSE unfortunately go unnoticed by many fans of anime, anime that does not have the usual that we see in other barely nibbled and that without a doubt the ara cry, get excited about and get angry with some of the situations that happen in this great anime the Opening We're not alone-starring Coldrain is absolutely amazing as well as the beautiful ending to the Far off Distance-starring Galneryus in addition the background music between guitars and violins as well as electronic music this anime is without doubt a jewel that cannot pass, i have to say that there was a time when little left by the anime for what happened In chapter 12, but even so I continued to look and it was worth it totally worth even that I feel sad for what happened on that cap, a point in favor of this anime is how despite the fact that, as any anime has a Prota anime develops every aspect of each of the characters their dreams and go ahead with a smile and overcoming the evidence that the destination sets before them only to return under that tree in which the 7 guys carved their dreams and they promised that they would be seen, this is a very sad anime even more that Clannad and Angel Beats and that is already say much..

This anime was not what I expected it to be. I expected to be how I usually am with anime--excited to watch it only then to take forever just to move on to the next episode. By the time I had finished the first episode, I knew that I was totally wrong. I could barely stop watching it.
The story is so interesting yet so grim and dark that you can't help but feel bad for the characters. As you watch it, you just want the best for these characters because of everything they've gone through.
The songs are amazing. The opening's awesome and makes you hypedup to watch the anime and the ending is a good cool down song that makes you just want to process everything that's happened. The OSTs are also very memorable and fitting.


The art's really unique. You don't really see anime with that type of art. It actually matches the art style of the manga. The animation is good as well.


The characters seem complex and human enough. They're definitely not self inserts. They're characters with personalities of their own that you, as a watcher, can relate to and understand.


There's no big issue with this anime...it's just a few small ones. The first issue is about the characters backstories. They didn't really go into the backstories of Soldier and Cabbage. If you're not paying attention to that, then it won't seem like too much of a problem. As a person who was looking forward to learning more about Soldier and Cabbage, I was a bit disappointed.


The next issue is with...a certain event. There was a very important and serious moment in this anime and I just felt like it could've played out a bit differently. It was supposed to be a moment when the viewer got emotional and sad. It worked but only partially. Even though I was extremely sad while it was happening, I just kept saying "why?" over and over again in my head. The way certain things happened then was almost weird in a way. But, again, if you're not looking into it very much, then I doubt that you'll see anything wrong with it.


Story: 9

Art: 10

Sound: 10

Characters: 10

Enjoyment: 10


Overall, Rainbow: Nisha Rokubou no Shichinin is a mature anime with substance. Despite it's flaws, I say that it still earns a 10.

There is graphic violence and a LOT of moments that will make you cringe... this is not for the faint of heart. That being said, this is an excellent anime. If you can take ups and downs and some heartache this is one of the most powerful tales of friendship and comradery I've ever seen in any medium. You will cry from pure emotion at how strong the bond is between the Criminal Seven from Cell Block 2-6. I strongly recommend basically everyone watch this one.
Story: 8/10
This is where you may dislike the story a bit if you're a perfectionist. There are quite a fewplot drivers that are unrealistic and thinking them through too much makes big chunks of the story fall apart. Trying to avoid spoilers, the boys have dirt on the head of the prison they are in and this causes them to catch a LOT of animosity. That being said, they have several instances of contact with the outside world where they could get that info to the media and fix their circumstances (though this would remove the source of drama). 


Putting that aside, the story is fantastic if you aren't looking to ruin it. Everything ties together nicely, there are huge ups and downs. In the end, everything is resolved and nothing feels rushed; you know the ending of all characters and you will feel satisfied that you know their futures. It is a miracle that the last episode does such an excellent job of wrapping everything up, I never would have guessed.


Art: 9/10

I love the character models; each of the boys is unique and the choice for hyper realism only enhanced the grittiness of the story. The use of colors truly elevates or darkens the mood.


Sound: 9/10

Excellent cast of voice actors. Everyone sounds exactly as you'd imagine them sounding. The music enhances the mood... the way the intro song plays into the last episode is epic.


Character: 10/10

This is where the anime truly shines. The characters are all amazing; good or evil they are all done SO well. You understand everyone's emotions and the cast is truly diverse (complex characters like Mario and Undercover and simple characters like Cabbage and Soldier). They manage to bring in new characters even into the last episode that will have you on an emotional roller coaster. Characters go through trials and tribulations and truly grow; the one thing that is unwavering is the bond the 7 boys have with each other.


Enjoyment: 10/10

I enjoyed every episode. I couldn't wait for the next one! The only thing that set me back was the dread that things could go wrong... that is the vibe of the anime; at any moment something could go wrong. In the end I found this most enjoyable.


Overall: 9/10

If you let slide the plot holes and the grimness/grittiness that exists, this anime is a masterpiece. Maybe it is because of those things it is a masterpiece. I suggest everyone who hasn't seen this watch it!

While very idealized, this show is a good portrayal of post WWII Japan and of general Japanese-American sentiment.  You get a look at the internal problems that were plaguing the nation during the war and afterwards.  The show gets you to hate characters you're supposed to hate, and to love characters you're supposed to love.  It also looks good.  So basically, it's a good and well-made anime.  My only problems with it were a soundtrack that didn't always reflect the tone of the events that they were playing behind, and characters that, for me, seemed to fall flat when thinkingabout more than whether or not they're badass and good shonen heroes and whatever (@Mario and Sakuragi).  Generally, this show had a lot of potential with its setting and story, but the music and characters didn't allow it to reach the heights that it could have with its premise.  \n\n
It's still a pretty good watch though.  I highly recommend it ^_^

(writing this review just finishing the 16th episode.)
You know when a show is really good? when it can pull you in and pour gasoline on you to blaze up your emotions. And boy do we have a roller-coaster on our hands here. 
Rainbow is a story taking place right after WWII, of 7 kids going through their day's in a correction facility. due to either criminal behavior or unfortunate circumstances.
Starting off I was pretty worried about Rainbow having a cast of 7 people in it's main roster. which is quite difficult, considering you have to get us attached to each individual in the group foreverything to really matter. And while some members of the group get a little less attention they still have an active and heartfelt role in the group. I was convinced some where just going to act as padding but I was thankfully wrong. 


If I did have some issue on the characters it would have to be the "villains". Don't get me wrong they're not written bad at all, but they come a across just a little too cartoonishly "evil" at some points, which just felt a little over the top for this kind of series. I'd have like to see a tad more of a realistic take, or at least some redeemable qualities to make them a bit more human.


One of the strongest aspects of Rainbow is it's atmosphere. there's a lot of suspenseful moments that reward you greatly. the gritty and dirty feeling inside the prison feels very genuine and you know any positive moment can easily backlash to something else. Which just keeps you on edge numerous times. even if you know what's coming you're still eager to see how it play's out. Aside from sad and content I even got Angry at the results of certain scenario's. It made me realize how invested I was 

in the moment. 


Lets see what else..., Animation and Music...pffttt it's Madhouse we're talking about here! They don't have to prove themselves. it's all solid in this department!


So far the only "bad" thing about the entire series is episode 13. and that's only because it's the re-cap episode. For the story it's trying to tell and the way they tell it the anime is practically flawless up to this point.


I just hope they can live up to my expectations for the second half.

but even still I don't see myself scoring Rainbow with anything lower then a 9 at this point.

I gave it an 8 because while I enjoyed the series and I think it's one of the most unique anime's i've seen so far it still suffers from some issues.
(I'm not really good in reviews but I'll try also there will be some spoilers)
story
the story is basically divided into 2 parts,  the first is the characters struggle in jail and the second is their struggle in the outside world.
I think the story was well executed but I think they should have done more of the first part than the second part, as for me.
during the second half, I don't feel any pity fromthe characters anymore, not like in the first part where I scream once they fight or I cringe wheenever Ishihara did something stupid again.


another thing that is it has some plot holes like how did Rokurouta end up in jail, I still dont understand it, also we have no soldier arc, I also think Cabbage, Uncovered and Turtle's arc we're weak as there are no real struggle for them.

Mario also got two arcs and I think his arm should have been healed a while ago.


Characters

while they are all likable (expect for the villains), I find them all forgettable, maybe because Sakuragi really shines in the entire series, in which I think is also their downfall because the series has become Sakuragi-centric. to the point where they treat him like a God or so and heck even Mario ends up looking like sakuragi.


Setsuko is an okay character at least once her purpose is done she's done, she's kinda weak though, the villains in this episodes are kinda okay, they are cringy enough for you to hate them.

they are sadistic in their own way and I couldnt be happier on how did they got Punked.


back with the main characters, yeah I like their determination and at the same time you really will feel bad for them, It's true that you won't pity them on the second half but still i think you will be satisfied on how did they achieved their goals.


Sound and Animation

The sound is pretty nice, the opening was pretty BADASS.. and I like Joe's cover of Jailhouse Rock, you can definetely feel the atmosphere in jail once you heard the OST's and it will take you back to the 50s.


The animation was okay, another flaw i think is again Mario and Sakuragi's design outshined all of them, not even Joe's  blond hair could stop them, still I think it was good, I like the colors appearing while the narration happens and I like Dear night, It could have been perfect while in a certain sad scene.


Enjoyment

Yes I did enjoy it nothing else

"I get by with a little help from my friends" -The Beatles 
Let's be honest, when I first saw this anime listed on MAL, the title and the poster with all the angsty looking boys kinda gave me the wrong impression, but maybe that's what was needed for me to discover this hidden gem of an anime. Watching this anime was like a riding a rollercoaster of emotions and for the first time in ages I found myself yelling at my computer in fear or excitement for the characters as the story progressed. 
The story is about not about the type of "boys love" thatthe title led me to believe but its the type of boys love that makes you all warm and fuzzy inside -- a story about trust, betrayal, forgiveness, loyalty, and knowing that even though life throws you some fucked-up shit your true friends will always be there to take that shit with you or help you kick its ass. Set in the backdrop of post WWII Japan, similar to that in Grave of the Fireflies, the war and its end had taken its toll on its citizens and its repercussions exhibit themselves in the Japanese youth. The pacing is excellent as well, not too long and not too short. I'm surprised that the producers were able to fit a good amount of material in 26 episodes without me feeling like they were dragging the story at all. 


The use of a darker color palette was very appropriate in that it helped set the dark tone and the bleak world that the boys were living in. The color scheme also sort of gave it a historic feel for some reason, felt like I was watching Rurouni kenshin. The music, specifically the intro song "You're not alone" by coldrain, which had a style reminiscent of the type of music I listened to in my high school days, I felt captured the teenage angst portrayed by the characters, while preaching lyrics of hope and perseverance. Yes I had to download the song and listened to it many times. 


The characters are truly what make this anime special. The 26 episode length does an almost perfect job at developing each character and telling their stories. I can't even explain without spoiling... you just have to see for yourself. Its like you become part of their little group as you watch more and more... you will cry (and/or yell at the computer) when when bad shit happens to them or when someone tries to screw them over, you will cry when their hearts are broken, you will cry when they cry manly tears of happiness. I don't think I can cry for another year. And that's how much I love these characters. The evil baddies are EVIL and YOU WILL HATE THEM.

*Also on a side note --- An-chan and Mario are total hotties, for those of you who appreciate a little man candy.


This anime surprisingly plays up a few different themes -- has a little bit of sports, a little romance, a little bit of music, etc, which made it entertaining to watch. Together with its gripping story, amazing cast of characters, and satisfying ending, I think people should give this anime a chance. Sure there's a lot of adult themes explicitly illustrated to help tell the story (You will likely be disturbed with the amount of violence and sexual abuse), I think that it was necessary to get you (or me at least) to really sympathize with the characters. But with struggles and obstacles, you really get to see the characters shine when they overcome them with a little help from their friends.

"What is life without happiness?"   
    Before I start this review I should first point out that this anime wasn't suppose to a action or an overly suspenseful anime, instead it's suppose to be a show about ex inmates from a disciplinary school and their life after being free. So if you're disappointed in this anime because it moved from the addicting setting inside the school to a more of a slice of life, drama anime outside of prison then you are disrespecting this anime since the anime wasn't intended to be about them in disciplinary school but out ofit.

   Story: Rainbow: Nisha Rokubou no Shichinin in my opinion has the best story I've ever seen, its unoriginal setting separates it from all the animes that we love. The story is about ex inmates and their struggles after getting free and how their friendship develops, this shows a real life situation since in our society ex inmates are actually having a hard time blending into and being accept by society. It delivered a different and realistic setting in a form of anime which we never get a chance to see anywhere else, what surprised me is how much this show is underrated with only about 107 000 members. WTF


   Sound and Art: The art is very sharp and smartly coordinated, it's not abstract at all instead it's very sharp and detailed as if it was a real tv show, its sharpness is to the point before it gets weird, good work on that part! The sound is pretty regular and nothing special, it has a attractive 1:15min opening where you can feel emotional even in that.


   Characters: Some character is extremely developed while some are brushed off to the side and said "you probably know what this character is like without a background story", a clear example of this is Matsuura, Mansaku (Cabbage). Characters like Yokosuka, Jou(Joe) orMaeda, Noboru (Turtle) has their background shown and really focuses on how they develop. Overall the character are either well done or brushed off to the side, but the ones that are well done deserves a round of applause and are worthy in your favourites list!


   Overall: This show was very enjoyable and emotion as I gripped my blanket holding back any physical emotions (Such as crying :P). I would recommend this anime to anyone who watches anime in general, it's a must see.

                        Things to take out of this anime

                               1. Value your friends

                               2. Respect your parents

                               3. Appreciate with what you have

                               4. Forgive others

                               5. Work hard

                               6. Never give up

Wow. This anime was just.....wow. It was a roller-coaster. If you don't mind getting caught up in your feelings, I'd highly recommend watching this. Fair warning: it's a psychological anime, so it'll fuck with your mind a little bit.  
10/10 Story: VERY unique. I don't believe I've ever watched an anime like this before. It's actually in a way realistic. It just draws you in from the beginning. You have these broken characters and you want to know why they're so broken. After episode 14, I did feel that it dragged on a little bit. Nonetheless, it was still amazing. Crazy good plot.
----------
10/10 Art:Very refreshing art. Some of the best art I've seen in a long time. It gave me Attack On Titan art vibes and I just loved it. \n
----------\n
8/10 Sound: I REALLY loved the ending and opening songs. They were great. One was in English and that surprised me. It's kind of rock n' roll and that was a plus for me.\n
-----------\n
10/10 Characters: Great character development. Not all of the characters were likable (watch the anime and you'll find out why). However, every character did serve a purpose. The main characters all came to specific realizations in their lives.\n
-----------\n
Overall 8/10: It wasn't the best anime I've ever watched, but it was pretty damn good. I honestly wish there was a little more romance. The ending was good, although I would've changed it a little bit. Overall, I think it's a great anime.

DaikiClub Bro Time-Saver Review:
BLUF: Rainbow Nisha is absolutely fantastic and if you like emotional yet entertaining stories, this is the anime for you. 9/10
Story- The story is a mixture of episodic and overarching theme. The 7 young men are all detention kids and the overall theme is their transformation to successful men, rather than hoodlums. The episodic stories provide the key elements for character development. The stories have a few twists and turns, but are mostly just classic "friendship and effort conquers all" stories.
Art- The art is solid and I liked it, but there's nothing special. The one unique thing that some people may hateis there is alot of narration over frozen shots. The still images have a drawn feel to them and I kind of liken it to narration over the manga. I liked it.


Sound- The opening track, voices, score, and narration are all godly. That is all.


Characters- The main characters all develop and have arcs to them. I think the show did a fantastic job creating likable, yet dichotic young men. From the opening scene to the closing conversation you have an emotional tie to the characters and you want to watch more.


Enjoyment- If you like emotional things that aren't over feminized or all romantic, this is the anime for you. I loved it. There were scenes that made me legitimately happy, sad, and angry.  It's only 26 episodes and you'll probably clear it in a couple weeks tops. 


TL;DR- Watch this anime, it's awesome.

For myself, the hardest reviews are the creative works that have given me a mixed reaction. If I feel something's bad, it's easy to pick out the numerous flaws, and if I feel something's good, it's easy to pick out the numerous strengths. Mixed bag shows, however, gravitate somewhere in the middle of these two opposites. As much as they do wrong, they also do right. 
Rainbow, unfortunately, falls in this mixed bag category. I say unfortunately because the show had a crazy amount of potential from the get-go. A historical drama set in a reformatory school during post-war Japan? That sounds great already. Andyou know what? There were actually moments of brilliance in this anime. That's why it makes this all the more disappointing that Rainbow never truly lived up to its potential. 


If I break down Rainbow's negatives, I'm left with three major problems. First, this anime has a tendency to needlessly force drama onto the characters and plot. For example, there were several times that characters, who were good and at some point underwent character development, suddenly had face-heel turns without an ounce of foreshadowing. This, along with the variety of small-time assholes that are attracted to the main cast like Winny the Pooh is to honey, gives the impression that their sole existence in this show is to create drama for the plot. I get that post-war Japan was not the best place, but there's only so much of the same drama you can create before it gets predictable. 


Second, every time that goddamn narrator pops in when the show's art goes all pastel. If you ever wanted to know what the anime equivalent of when video games beat unnecessary tutorials over their players' heads was, then here you go. Seriously, every time this happens, it's so damn distracting. It stops whatever is happening in the story, usually a dramatic moment, so the writers can tell the viewers what is going. Is it REALLY that necessary to tell me what Mario is thinking? Think back, have you ever had a teacher tell you that, in your writing, you should "show" not "tell"? Can't the studio just show me what he's thinking through his actions, or do they have to explain to me everything like we're all morons. There were countless times when I was trying to interpret out a character's actions or words, when suddenly, the narrator chimes in to tell you the exactly how to interpret the current scene. If I'm not allowed to think about what I'm watching, and draw my own conclusions, why in the hell am I bothering to watch it in the first place? In a different context, it would be borderline propaganda.


Third, Rainbow has a lot of build up, and it can be great, but the payoff doesn't usually live up to it. Around halfway through the show, there is a potentially series defining scene, but is ruined because the whole situation surrounding the scene seemed easily avoidable. With a few exceptions, this reoccurs in every arc of Rainbow.


What makes this all the more painful is that Rainbow really isn't a bad show. It does have standout moments that are suspenseful, tragic, and heartfelt. That's what surprising about this anime. Just when you're about to write off, it does something really cool. And then the narrator speaks up and ruins everything.

Rainbow: Nisha Rokubou no Shichinin
When I first layed my eyes on Rainbow I didn't think much of it.
An anime about the life of being in jail, sounds pretty simple right? But boy was I wrong. Inmate Sakuragi knowing of a dark secret that unfolded years ago in the Reform Jail. Is haunted endlessly by a corrupt guard & perverted Doctor, who's goal is nothing more than keep that dark secret from reaching the light of day. Forcing Sakuragi in an empty life behind bars. Following this exhilarating story of the bonds of friendship, dreams, & the struggle for survival. Our main characters look to aidtheir fellow cell mate Sakuragi from the evil clutches of the antagonists. With no stop in the constant flow of action, even dare to blink and you're guaranteed to miss a good part. There's no denying how absolutely brutal and hard of a tone this anime is. Masters at expressing these dark tones, the violent atmosphere, & the realness of the anime. Makes it one of the best thriller anime's I've watched to date. Definitely not something for the weak of heart, sorry kids!


Let's not get hung up on only the story though. Rainbow deserves a lot more praise than just on its amazing plot. The music choice that is used in Rainbow deserves some too. It's like listening to a track brought down by the Angels themselves. I don't think they could of used any better music than what they did. As well as using those glorious tunes in the right moment is also key, which btw they nailed. I found myself even humming the songs. I guarantee you that there is no episode that wont have a song worthy of a place in your playlist.


Alternately, another thing going for Rainbow is the characters. Emphasizing again on the realness of the anime. The characters are portrayed in a manner that complements the anime's heaviness.

The showing of many different layers each character has. The feelings that you get, where its almost as if you are watching real people go through these hardships. The emotional impact that each character undergoes, makes it almost impossible not to sympathize with them.


Less enjoyable factors about Rainbow do exist however.

The art isn't anything that will have your jaw dropping. This isn't necessarily a bad thing though. It's not like it makes me gauge my eyes out or anything. It's just completely average, nothing really special about it except for a something here and there. Rainbow also suffers from pacing issues. The story takes a hit here, where the 2nd half of the anime feels rushed in episodes. Almost as if we're skipping from one idea to the next.


Nevertheless, I still greatly enjoyed Rainbow. From the speechless emotional moments, to the fantastic music produced. I would recommend this for anyone mature enough to take it.

A life detriment by the horrors of the unknown, unfaithful, and miserable. These six fellows face challenge after challenge with no happiness but their own found friendships.  The story takes place during the aftermath of the Attack on Pearl Harbor, in where the Americans dropped an atomic bomb on Japan. This event plunges Japan into a certain unlawful darkness. It is now up to these fellows to find a way to survive and live out their dreams.
The characters in this anime are extraordinarily well done in terms of background. Piece by piece each character is unraveled to the viewer, allowing us to understand howthey ended up in such a situation. Each character is distinct and adds their own perspective to the matter at hand, allowing for complex problems to be solved in really interesting ways at times.


The dark and gruesome anime surprisingly sheds an extreme amount of light onto the viewer by turning outrageous situations into hopeful circumstances.


Story - 10 - The plot is implicitly defined from the start of the anime, which begins to morph at a climax in the story into numerous dreams to be fulfilled. The great part is that each dream turns into a story of its own.

Graphics - 9 - Great lighting, water effects, character expressions, and detailed action scenes.

Sound - 9 - Big thumbs up mainly because I am a rocker fan.

Characters - 10 - Astounding job on the background stories and distinct nature of each character, plus the portraying of evil characters.


Overall - 9.5 Wicked anime. It almost tortured my soul to watch certain events take place and the anime kept me thoroughly enthralled, however because of the dark nature I felt I couldn't finish the anime in one night.

Recommended - Absolutely! Especially since the anime is so different from other anime that I have watched.

Wow, what a ride. Before I started to watch the fist episode of this anime, I thought to myself "I hope that this is anime start off with a bang." In fact, it started off with an explosion! Out of the anime that I've seen so far, this is one that tackles a genuine and honest theme. The theme of loyalty, bravery, and sacrifice for people other than yourself. 
Trust is something that is earned. This anime teaches you that even though people and this world may be cruel, there is a friend in this world that you are destined to meet. This friend willalways have your back and stick with you through the very end. Even if you do not have that friend right now, this anime becomes that comfort for you. 


The characters were well built starting from the first episode. There are a few characters who do not get as developed as others but this doesn't take away from the anime at all. The art style throughout the anime can be dark but then comforting and bright at times. The sound and music for this series is pretty good. The intro and ending themes are masterpieces. 


In retrospect, I cannot praise this anime enough. My enjoyment for this show overflows. Keep in mind that this anime does contain some graphic/gory scenes. However, it's an anime about overcoming life's obstacles. 


I present to you, the POWERFUL series of Rainbow: Nisha Rokubou no Shichinin. Enjoy.

Intro:
This show presents the darkness of reality, a violent world filled with betrayal, madness, deceit and injustice. It shows coruption at its finest, the post-war way of living and dying in the japanese prison and the outside life that awaits a former convict. Rainbow shows us how important it is to have dreams and how important it is to have friends that help you follow those dreams
Story: 8/10
Rainbow tells the story of seven teenagers who are found guilty of serious crimes and are sent to a disciplinary school that ultimately becomes their hell. Rainbow thells the story of seven close friends and their path tofreedom as well as presenting their pain and sacrifice. The plot is well planned but it does have plot holes such as Sakuragi’s death etc and is predictable at times. I really loved the brotherhood theme of the story.


Some of the plot holes:

- It is said that Sakuragi „killed” his father but his father commited suicide, how did Sakuragi end up in a disciplinary school?

- If the boys in the reformatory can go to the library whenever the please, why do they hang out in the cell?

- How come noone investigated the fire that almost killed 7 inmates?

- Why does a doctor seem to control the disciplinary school?

- When Sakuragi is made to starve and the good guard tries to help Sakuragi, the antagonists kill the good guard. Why is it easier to kill a fellow gurad that to kill a convict?

- Why was Ishihara not arrested for stabbing Sakuragi?

- No arc for Soldier?



Characters: 8/10

The characters have various diffrent personalities that change and develop over time. They all have  interesting backstories and each of them has someting unique about themselves. The character development is also very good, for example Mario is portayed in the begining to be weak and in the end presented as a man that can take care of himself or Baremoto who gradually developed from not trusting anyone to making life-long friends he would take a bullet for. The antagonists were well built becoming very real and frightening. 


I felt like the creator had a misogynistic side, almost every women either has ill intent and is deceitful or she has to sell her body in order to achieve her goals. For example, Baremoto’s mother sold her body for food, Lilly had to sell her body to the american general, hoping to get a visa for the U.S., Jon’s manager uses him as a sex slave, Joe’s orphanage director used him as a sex slave, etc.

I also disliked how the relationship between Mario and the nurse, Setsuko ended. Even though Setsuko and Mario loved each other, described as „blinding love”, she agreed to be engaged with another „rich” man. Even though the night before her wedding day, they confessed their love and Setsuko had sex with Mario she still went on and got married. I once heard a joke: „Love him for who he is not for his money. He is a man not a bank”, I think this applies to Setsuko’s case but on the other hand, maybe she was waiting for Mario to fight for her.


Animation: 8/10

As expected of Madhouse, artwork and character design successfully captures the gloomy and depressing atmosphere of the post-war Japan. Animation in general was nothing fancy, but consistent throughout the series and relatively pleasing to the eye. I think the dark and gloomy artstyle and collors are very well suited to the theme of the anime.


Sound: 8/10

The opening theme „We’re not alone” and the ending are very good. They both do an excellent job of conveying the message of bonds and not giving up, which showcases the show's values perfectly. The show itself doesn't have a lot of music but when there is music it does work very well in tandem with the show and does a good job of capturing the mood.


Enjoyment: 8/10

The first arc was very good and interesting while the arcs that followed were weaker but still failry interesting.


Overall: 7.0/10

Rainbow is a good and intriguing anime series that may be boring at times but ends up being interesting I would recommend Rainbow to anyone who is able to stomach this kind of anime.

Rainbow:  Nisha Rokubou no Shichinin is THE best anime I have ever watched so far.  
Story - 10/10  The story followed 6 young people who were sent to shonen reformatory and the struggles they go through.  I think it's based on how important friendship is, and I usually don't really care about that because it's so common, but the ties between the characters in Rainbow is are just so touching and heart warming...   It is filled with drama and the storyline is just so great.  There's some cheesy parts here and there but they're well done.  There'svery little anime that interests me as much as this one.  I really like the setting too, because a lot of animes now adays are about people in school, or a harem, or people with super powers.  Rainbow is a nice change of pace, since it was set in a dark prison place and after a war in Japan.


Art - 9/10  I know everyone has different tastes in art, but a lot of anime art icks me.  I really liked the art in this anime though, it's clean and doesn't have the oversized eyes stuff.  The body proportions are well done too, since a lot of anime make the female characters look like 10 year olds and give them eyes that take up half of their head and a tiny body.  However, it may take a few episodes to get used to it if you're used to watching anime with big eyes/colored hair/ etc...


Sound - 10/10  I really liked the opening song.  It fit the anime really well, and the songs played at each scene also fit the mood.  The soundtracks in this anime were really epic and beautiful.


Character - 9/10  The characters here aren't the usual Mary/Gary Stu or Tsunders, they have real personalities, and in realistic personalities have flaws.  Each of the characters have their own flaws, but flaws are what makes a character lovable.  Another thing I like is that they didn't make the male characters all "bishies" or extremely good looking.  I gave it a 9/10 instead of a 10/10 because sometimes I feel that the antagonists are  such completely screwed up @ssholes that it's not really realistic.  It's like they're 100% evil with no ounce of non-evil in them xD.


Enjoyment - 10/10 hands down.  Didn't bore me, didn't annoy me, kept me longing for the next episode until I found out there was no more...


Overall - 10/10  I can't believe how this show isn't that popular.  This is definitely the best anime I have ever watched (so far)

I have to say, I was taken aback when I watched the first episode, which prompted me to place the series on hold – I thought it was too much for me. 
And it turned out to be quite true: Rainbow is pretty ruthless when it comes to addressing issues you almost never see in anime and very rarely even see in mainstream media. Police brutality, prison guards running amuck, corruption within the penitentiary system, and, of course, the consequences of WWII for Japan itself. 
The story is told from the point of view of the primary characters and swings back and forth between all ofthem, not to an equal degree, but all of them get decent screen time. Each episode has a story to it that is horrifically relatable. The suspense was definitely very well executed, and the honesty of the story - without embellishments, realistic endings – was what made it amazingly good. 


The art is very well done, it is the type of art that I personally enjoy in anime, and certain highlights of the scenes that mattered were executed very well. The character designs were memorable and ever-evolving. 


The soundtrack is amazing – though some people dislike the opening, I find it incredibly good and very summarizing to the rest of the series. 


I enjoyed every moment of the characters' journey and I really wish there were more of such bare, honest stories in anime today.

Also thay did a great job with the soundtrack . I hate to admit it but i listen every day every single one of the soundtracks. Finally i will say 2-3 words for this anime : it is back at the end of the 2nd world war , and some kids go tojail for punishment after some crims they did. There they meet a guy which at first they didnt like and pike a fight with him but in the end he is their BRO . One of the best anime , its must watch. thaink u for reading this :)

Rainbow is a show about the criminal seven of cell 2-6. Seven boys who, for better or worse, get sent to a disciplinary school and form a deep bond of friendship. Throughout the show, this friendship deepens and we get a lot more depth as these characters develop from beginning to end. Now let me just say, the show isn't as graphic as I expected but if you don't want to see implied rape or anything of the sort, I recommend skipping this show. If you can handle A Clockwork Orange, you'll be fine though.
Let's get a few negatives out of the way here first,because they are rather large. One of the biggest negatives in the series is that it is very vague about why these boys ended up in cells. I like my stories to generally be a little more full circle. Now it doesn't detract from the show, but in the end you are left wondering why. Another big negative is one of the characters at the end doesn't get his own arc. Now this is due to the show ending before the manga, but it's an oversight. One episode would have been plenty, as another character had only a one episode arc and it was one of the best in the show.


The overall story of Rainbow in the first half of the show is actually the weakest part. Now I don't say this to be negative, it's actually pretty amazing, because the first half of the show is gripping. The story of these boys going through their struggles was dark, but when the second half came around and we got character arcs for all of them, ones that are so emotionally touching and well made, I couldn't help but see the show a bit differently. How it builds up the darkness in the first half to something much brighter in the second. It was beautifully deliberate, but it never felt like it was.


Characters had memorable nicknames, memorable backstories and very memorable arcs. Some of the most emotionally gripping arcs I've seen in anime, and they each made me tear up by the end. The buildup all led to an emotional payoff. Something I don't see much in many anime. There was an amount of closure in each arc that felt so satisfying. Another one of the biggest positives here that I have to mention. Villains. By gods, did this show do villains brilliantly. Sure, they were fairly one dimensional, but my god, I still hated them. 


Now there's a lot of cheese in this show. It's melodramatic. Although I never once felt any sense of cringe in the type of melodrama presented. Rather, it felt very real and very well-done. The two big negatives in the series itself do hurt it. I was torn honestly. I wanted to give the show that perfect score, but these negatives really do make the show feel somewhat incomplete, which is unfortunate. But don't let that stop you, Rainbow is a feels trip. It will make you angry, laugh, cry and really feel for the struggles of each character. It's a must watch. It's a cheesy 1950s melodrama with a ton of heart put into making it, and it deserves your attention.

At the time of this review, I've dropped Rainbow after episode 14. If I ever finish watching and change my opinion, I'll come back to re-edit, but for now this is my opinion on the show so far. There are spoilers in this review.
Story: 7/10. A serviceable story that gives insight into a time period that isn't well-known yet holds a lot of history. As the telling of a group of boys that learn how to stick together and bear the brunt of their tragedies, I think the show does a pretty good job but isn't without its flaws. After the group escapes from theprison, I found the story to be somewhat contrived and poorly paced. There seems to be an unevenness to the progression of the characters in the 'first arc' of the story. The episodes in the prison are well done and really underline the characters struggles; when the characters escape the prison, things feel rushed and contrived; and finally, when we end at the 'redemption' arc, things are too weirdly paced and left a sour taste in my mouth. 




Art: 9/10. Really good.


Sound: 7/10. Outside of the opening and ending, I didn't really find any interesting tracks.



Character: 6/10. Given the show takes place in a realistic setting and is meant to depict a piece of history, it's to be expected that the characters won't be as dynamic or fantastical as characters you'd see in shounen. As a result, some people might perceive them as bland and too mediocre, which I think is an unfair criticism given that these characters aren't meant to be wide stretches of the imagination: they are depicting real people who suffered very real problems for the time period they live in. In this vein, the story does a good job at portraying this.


But the problem lies in how the story tries to motivate its plot through its characters in seemingly contrived ways. The biggest offender in my opinion is Bro's character, as he is the best character in the series and yet is utilized in almost insulting ways.


Bro's character hinges on loyalty to his friends, yet he decided to offend his dead friend by giving the annoying prisoner officer his suicide note, the last piece of evidence that could prove his friend's death was caused by corruption of the prison staff. I don't think Bro would EVER insult his friends, dead or alive, by doing this; yet to motivate the plot and have Bro die, the show decides to write this in. It's lazy writing imo and it takes away from who Bro is and what he stands for, and it really just puts a damper on everything the characters went through prior to this moment.


Also, although I've stated prior that the characters aren't meant to be fantastical or particularly engaging and deep, this doesn't mean the show's characters will captivate everyone. Even I have a hard time getting invested into personal characters, and the friendship dynamic is really the only engaging aspect all these characters share. Outside of this, the tragedies of the characters are either glossed over or not given due attention.



Enjoyment: 7/10. I really liked how the show started out, and would rate the episodes taking place in the prison as a 10/10. However, after they escape, the show steadily declines until it became painfully dull and uninteresting. I ended up dropping the show, but I might go back to continue.


Overall: 7/10. I can see why people on both sides like or hate this show. It has a strong message but conveys it through characters are pretty bland on their own.

WHY IS NO ONE WATCHING THIS SHOW?! No one talks about it, no one talked about it when it came out. No one hyped it up. I don't get it. This should be seen by more people. It tells probably the most refined story of perseverance ever told in not only anime,but in any type of visual media,What am I talking about?
Rainbow: Nisha Rokubou no Shichinin (Rainbow:The Seven Criminals of Compound Two, Cell Six) is a long term tail of these seven teenagers, in disciplinary Shounan Special Reform School which is kinda like Juvie in the US, but in this show, these kids are prettymuch treated like criminals. These delinquents go through SO MUCH SHIT, and this is only the first half, I thought these people were straight up adults but then someone said they were like sixteen or seventeen, HOW? This show takes place after WW2 in Japan, but no way they treat kids like this. They get beaten for the smallest reasons and they suffer not only pain but also humiliation.But after every punch, they heal and grow more with the help of their superior, Sakuragi. It is violent of course, but there is a reason why instead of showing craziness for the sake of it. Before each episode,there is a disclaimer explaining why it is violent.Cuz it was like that back then. This show's first half is pretty much Shawshank Redemption but the second half of the show is soooo much better. The adversity in the second half is more organic and similar to what real-life is like and it speaks out more. One thing that might be unreliable  for some but a message i appreciate is how hard things get, a friend will help. It may sound cheesy, but whether it's a child's show or something more mature it is the case.It may not be like it now because this show takes place in the 50's, but if anyone asked of a show that really is a realistic example of overcoming hardship, this show would be my first recommendation(well at least the second half.)


Madhouse made and while watching this and Monster simultaneously is that madhouse doesn't focusing on having fluid animation when their main goal is capturing the tone of the time. From the lighting,setting, and character designs,Madhouse was portraying how depressing,but not depressing, time that was after WW2. The animation is not outstanding but it doesn't need to be cuz these people don't have magic powers. The best thing this show has visually is these still frames made with overpowering colors . This happens at least twice an episode and when it happens, that's when you know shit goes down .Sometimes when it happens, also I like how the show is colorful, but not.Sure the palette is depressing and soggy, but there are some very colorful scenes as well.



The opening in the show scared the crap out of me when I first saw it. It was made by coldrain,a band that is pretty much like"Fear and Loathing in LasVegas" except without the autotune and the techno piano. I like it because it's catchy as heck, but what is weird about the song, is that these singers are screaming at the camera but the lyrics are uplifting.The ending is beautiful, not only that but, its one of those songs that start of slow, but then it swells and is so harmonious. The OST is like a more refined version of all those motivational osts online but it is more refined and has a twist of western.It incorporates Whistling, harmonica and guitar. The main theme is not only the best part of the soundtrack, but one of my favorite pieces from anything. There is just so much passion put into it and then the fucking horns kick in and the entire scene becomes a pivotal moment. It is just pure genius


I'll try hard not to get into all of the characters because there are so many. Mario looks like he's the main character, but don't be fooled. Each episode focuses on each individual character and none of them get a good amount of screen time to be called a "main character".Sakuragi can be considered one, but he uhh....."takes a back seat" in the second half. Each character is given development and even more development to top it all off. The characters themselves are so wonderful together, they are a very good example of what Friendship is supposed to look like.There are seven characters: Mario, Joe, Cabbage,Turtle,Scam,Soldier, and Sakuragi(yes I remembered their nicknames and not their actual names).These guys are very down to earth human beings. Despite the crimes they were arrested for and the terrible things they go through, the are still just juvenile teens.They all have a motive and they stick to-- well not all of them at least:/ There will be at least one person that you will relate to.The people around them though, I feel like it kinda victimizes adults, because if one adult is not salty about the war, the other is in a bad condition and treats the boys like crap. There are some adults that aren't that bad and they help the boys, but they are not in the second half AT ALL.



People please, stop watching those depressiing shows and stop watching those slice of life anime that you hate because you know that your life will never be like that, this show is a great coming of age tale about redemption and the upsides to having friends, and heck, if you don't have friends, just get arrested and maybe you can......no.. actually don't get arrested, But still, I wish more people watched this show and praised it, The downside is that the show is not available anywhere legally, so you may have to pull some strings, but it's really worth people, I mean come on.


Overall-9

;-)

This review is going to be on the overall experience of watching Rainbow.
First of all, I consider this anime to be on the bond of those friends above all else, and this bond is whats make this anime so amazing in my opinion.
So, as a bunch of guys who meet in their first day of "jail", they fight this older dude, and by doing that, and getting beaten up, they establish their friendship with him.
The more you watch, the more that bond develops, and with that, the character development is there too. They werent bad kids in the first place, but you can see howmuch work the jail does on them to "punish" them, and by the end of the first part, we get the story set in stone.\n
The most amazing part of this is how the writer decided to continue the show after said first half, and that part, without spoilers, might annoy some people, but its just amazing to watch how the bond from those 6 kids is holding up and getting stronger as the story continues.\n
Its hard to say anything about this show without spoiling the main story, but here is my own view on this: I can connect with those characters on a personal level, as I myself went through a similar yet different kind of "jail", and there I found friends, although not as a strong bond as those in the show, but the similarity toyed with my feelings, which is for me is extremly rare.\n
All in all, I enjoyed the anime so much I didnt notice stuff like art or sound, but I believe that both of those were done correctly, as you would expect from a seinen anime.\n
Watch this show if you love brothely bonds and cool men.\n
Thanks for reading.
